topics.name: The Universe
topics.description: A vast expanse of space, time, and matter that includes everything we know.

topics.name: Origin of the Universe
topics.description: The Big Bang theory explains how the universe began 13.8 billion years ago.

topics.name: The Observable Universe
topics.description: The part of the universe we can see, limited by the speed of light and cosmic expansion.

topics.name: Expansion of the Universe
topics.description: The universe is continuously expanding, with galaxies moving away from each other.

topics.name: Cosmic Microwave Background
topics.description: Faint radiation left over from the Big Bang, providing clues about the early universe.

topics.name: Fate of the Universe
topics.description: The universe may end in a Big Crunch, Big Freeze, or Big Rip, depending on dark energy.

topics.name: Multiverse Theories
topics.description: Some theories suggest our universe is just one of many in a vast multiverse.

topics.name: Planets
topics.description: Celestial bodies orbiting stars, ranging from rocky to gas giants.

topics.name: Mercury
topics.description: The smallest planet and closest to the Sun, with extreme temperature variations.

topics.name: Venus
topics.description: A scorching hot planet with a thick, toxic atmosphere and runaway greenhouse effect.

topics.name: Earth
topics.description: Our home planet, the only known world to support life.

topics.name: Mars
topics.description: The Red Planet, with signs of ancient water and potential for future human missions.

topics.name: Jupiter
topics.description: The largest planet, a gas giant with a massive storm known as the Great Red Spot.

topics.name: Saturn
topics.description: Famous for its stunning ring system and dozens of moons.

topics.name: Uranus
topics.description: An ice giant with a tilted axis, causing extreme seasonal changes.

topics.name: Neptune
topics.description: A cold, windy planet with the fastest known winds in the solar system.

topics.name: Pluto
topics.description: A dwarf planet, now classified as a 'plutoid' due to its icy composition.

topics.name: Exoplanets
topics.description: Planets outside our solar system, some of which may be habitable.

topics.name: Moons
topics.description: Natural satellites orbiting planets or dwarf planets.

topics.name: Moon
topics.description: Our only natural satellite, with a rich history of human exploration.

topics.name: Phobos
topics.description: Small moon of Mars, discovered by Asaph Hall in 1877.

topics.name: Deimos
topics.description: Small moon of Mars, discovered by Asaph Hall in 1877.

topics.name: Io
topics.description: A moon of Jupiter, known for its active volcanoes and volcanic eruptions.

topics.name: Europa
topics.description: A moon of Jupiter, believed to have an ocean beneath its icy surface.

topics.name: Ganymede
topics.description: The largest moon in the solar system, with a subsurface ocean.

topics.name: Titan
topics.description: The largest moon of Saturn, with a thick atmosphere and liquid methane seas.

topics.name: Triton
topics.description: A large moon of Neptune, with a retrograde orbit and geologically active surface.

topics.name: Charon
topics.description: The largest moon of Pluto, discovered in 1978 by James Christy.

topics.name: Stars
topics.description: Massive spheres of hydrogen and helium undergoing nuclear fusion.

topics.name: The Sun
topics.description: The star at the center of our solar system, providing heat and light to Earth.

topics.name: Red Giants
topics.description: A late stage in a star’s life, expanding and cooling before collapsing.

topics.name: White Dwarfs
topics.description: Dense remnants of stars that have exhausted their nuclear fuel.

topics.name: Neutron Stars
topics.description: Extremely dense remnants of supernovae, sometimes forming pulsars.

topics.name: Black Holes
topics.description: Regions of space with gravitational pull so strong that not even light can escape.

topics.name: Supernovae
topics.description: The explosive death of a star, often leading to neutron stars or black holes.

topics.name: Galaxies
topics.description: Massive systems of stars, gas, and dark matter bound by gravity.

topics.name: The Milky Way
topics.description: Our home galaxy, a barred spiral with billions of stars.

topics.name: Andromeda
topics.description: Our nearest large galaxy, set to collide with the Milky Way in 4.5 billion years.

topics.name: Spiral Galaxies
topics.description: Galaxies with rotating arms, including the Milky Way.

topics.name: Elliptical Galaxies
topics.description: Spherical or elongated galaxies with little gas and older stars.

topics.name: Irregular Galaxies
topics.description: Galaxies without a defined shape, often influenced by gravity.

topics.name: Dwarf Galaxies
topics.description: Small galaxies with a few billion stars, often orbiting larger ones.

topics.name: Active Galaxies (Quasars, Blazars)
topics.description: Galaxies with supermassive black holes emitting massive energy.

topics.name: Black Holes
topics.description: Invisible objects with gravity so strong that nothing can escape.

topics.name: Wormholes
topics.description: Theoretical tunnels connecting distant points in space-time.

topics.name: Time Dilation
topics.description: Time slows down near massive objects or at high speeds.

topics.name: Dark Matter
topics.description: An invisible substance that makes up most of the universe’s mass.

topics.name: Dark Energy
topics.description: A mysterious force driving the accelerated expansion of the universe.

topics.name: Cosmic Microwave Background
topics.description: The oldest light in the universe, a remnant of the Big Bang.

topics.name: The Big Bang
topics.description: The explosive event that started the universe 13.8 billion years ago.

topics.name: The Great Filter (Fermi Paradox)
topics.description: Why haven’t we found intelligent alien life despite vast probabilities?

topics.name: Are We Alone?
topics.description: The ongoing search for extraterrestrial life in the universe.

topics.name: Universe’s Fate (Big Crunch, Big Freeze, Big Rip)
topics.description: Possible scenarios for how the universe will end.

topics.name: Missing Antimatter
topics.description: Why does our universe have more matter than antimatter?
